Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: The grandmother learns that a family member is dealing with a significant personal crisis.
Expectation2: Arrive on time for scheduled volunteer shifts
Situation2: They are the only volunteer assigned to unlock the facility and begin the service for people already waiting outside.
Story:
This morning, as I was pouring my coffee, my phone buzzed with a message from my daughter: “Grandma, can you call? It’s urgent.” My heart skipped. I knew my son had been struggling lately, but I hadn’t realized things had gotten so serious. As a grandparent, I’ve always prided myself on being the steady hand, the one everyone can count on for comfort and advice. I wanted to call her right away, to listen, to help, to be there for my family in this crisis.

But then I glanced at the clock. My volunteer shift at the community center starts in twenty minutes, and I’m the only one with the keys. People—some of them elderly, some with nowhere else to go—will already be waiting outside. If I’m late, the doors stay locked, and the service doesn’t start. They count on me, too.

I stood in the hallway, phone in one hand, keys in the other, torn between the voices of my family and the silent expectation of those waiting at the center. My chest tightened as I weighed who needed me more, feeling the pull of both worlds and the ache of not being able to give myself fully to either.
